call.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She calls her father every couple of days.
I think we should call a doctor.
call a doctor/the police/a cab etc
call a doctor/the police/a cab etc
call.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: You call someone on the phone
If you call to  someone, you shout at them to get their attention
He called to the driver to stop
call.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to use a word or name to describe someone or something in a particular way
call.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The other kids used to call me names, but I tried to ignore them.
Are you calling me a liar?
You may call it harmless fun, but I call it pornography.
call.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to have a particular name or title, or use a particular name or title for someone or something
call.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The arrow that appears on the screen is called a cursor.
My name’s Virginia, but my friends call me Ginny.
Do you want to be called Miss or Ms?
I prefer to be called by my middle name.
call.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to give someone or something the name they will be known by in the future
call.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: What are you going to call the new puppy?
They’ve decided to call the baby Louise.
call.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to ask or order someone to come to you
call.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Peter called the waitress over and ordered a large brandy.
Marcie was called up to the principal’s office.
call.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to arrange for something to happen at a particular time
call.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The Security Council has called an emergency session to discuss the crisis.
According to the law, the election must be called within the next two months.
call.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to say or shout something loudly so that someone can hear you
call.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: I heard someone calling in the distance.
‘I’m coming!’ she called down the stairs.
Sheila was just sneaking out when her mother called her.
She heard him call her name.
The foreman called to the workmen.
call.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to read names or numbers in a loud voice in order to get someone’s attention
call.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: When I call your name, go and stand in line.
call.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to tell someone that they must answer questions in a law court or in front of an official committee
call.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: The prosecution called its next witness.
They were called to give evidence at the trial.
call.translation[0].definitions[8].note_: Call is often passive in this meaning
call.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to stop at a house or other place for a short time to see someone or do something
call.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: She called round for a chat.
Let’s call on James on the way home.
I regularly called in at his office for news.
People often call into the library while they’re out shopping.
call.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: if a train, ship, bus etc calls at a place, it stops there for a short time
call.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: This train calls at all stations to Broxbourne.
call.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to guess which side of a coin will land upwards when it is thrown in the air, in order to decide who will play first in a game
call.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to risk the same amount of money as the player who plays before you in a poker game
call.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: to telephone someone
call.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: call for + NOUN
call for an end to something
Demonstrators have called for an end to the fighting.
call for somebody’s resignation
Opposition parties called for the president’s resignation.
call for action
The European Parliament have called for action on age discrimination.
call for a ban
French farmers have called for a ban on imports.
call for a boycott
In 1980 he called for a boycott of the Olympic Games.
call for a change
Scientists are calling for a change in the law.
call for an inquiry/investigation
Relatives have called for an inquiry into the causes of the plane crash.
call for a return to something
The prime minister called for a return to traditional Labour values.
call for reform
The Church has called for reform of the law.
call for the abolition of something
Human Rights groups have called for the abolition of the death penalty.
call for a ceasefire
The United Nations called for an immediate ceasefire.
call.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: when you speak to someone on the telephone
call.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: It’s cheaper to make calls after 6 pm.
I’ll give you a call at the weekend.
Were there any phone calls for me while I was out?
I received a call from an old friend last week.
call.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a loud sound that a bird or animal makes
call.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a shout that you make to get someone’s attention
call.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a visit, especially for a particular reason
call.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Sorry, Doctor Pugh is out on a call at the moment.
call.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a request or order for something or for someone to do something
a call to arms (=an order for people to fight against an enemy)
call.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Members obediently answered the calls for funds.
There have been calls for the secretary to resign.
call for somebody to do something
call.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: the decision made by a referee in a sports game
call.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: There may have been a few bad calls, but they’re making them for a reason.
judgment call (=a decision based on your personal judgment of a situation)
call.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: Don’t just say what you think I would like. It’s your call.
call.translation[1].definitions[7].defin: a message announced at an airport that a particular plane will soon leave
call.translation[1].definitions[7].examp: This is the last call for flight BA872 to Moscow.
call.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: He made a few calls and then went out.
I’ll give him a call later today.
At 11 in the evening we got a call from the police.
There was a phone call for you.
We’re sorry that we cannot answer your call right now.
I left a message for her but she didn’t return my call.
She’s expecting a phone call from Matt.
The call was transferred to his secretary.
She asked the switchboard to put the call through.
I had a phone call from Barbara in Australia.
This is just a quick call to make sure you’re OK.
Local calls are free at weekends.
I’d like to make a long-distance call.
Can I make a collect call to Florida, please?
You have to dial 9 first to make an outgoing call.
The police normally respond immediately to an emergency call.
They received a hoax call warning of a bomb in the building.
The £10,000 demand was made in an anonymous call to his home.
The heavy breathing sounded like a crank call.
call.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the use of computers to help people learn foreign languages
call.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: She called the airport to ask about flights.
I was told that the office was closed and to call tomorrow.
call.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to make a telephone call which is paid for by the person you are telephoning
call.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to arrange for a meeting or an election to happen at a definite time
call.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: The company called a shareholders’ meeting to discuss the takeover bid.
call.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: to make a short visit to a person or place in order to do something
call.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: If you decide not to go ahead, just return the policy within 15 days. No salesman will call.
call.translation[3].definitions[4].defin: to ask or order someone to come to a place
call.translation[3].definitions[4].examp: Mike was called into the manager’s office and told there was no longer a job for him.
They were called to give evidence before the committee.
call.translation[3].definitions[5].defin: to repay a loan or bond to a lender, usually before it is normally due to be repaid
call.translation[3].definitions[5].examp: Interest rates are so low now it’s unlikely the bonds will ever be called.
call.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: an attempt to speak to someone by telephone
call.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: Calls cost 36p a minute cheap rate, 48p at all other times.
If you wish to be added to the mailing list, please give me a call on the number above.
Andrew Walker telephoned this morning, and would like you to return his call as soon as possible.
call.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: a request or demand for someone to do something
call.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: He made a call for private companies to offer up to 25% of their shares to workers’ co-operatives.
call.translation[4].definitions[2].defin: a short visit, especially for a particular reason
call.translation[4].definitions[2].examp: I’ll pay a call on our supplier later this week.
call.translation[4].definitions[3].defin: a demand for money that can be made at any time and without warning, especially a demand for a loan to be repaid
call.translation[4].definitions[3].examp: There are $200 million in bearer bonds still outstanding, held by people who did not hear about a call.
call.translation[4].definitions[4].defin: if a bank lends money at call or on call, the bank can demand to have it paid back at any time and without warning
call.translation[4].definitions[4].examp: Overdrafts to customers are often granted for a few days or weeks. Some loans to other financial institutions may be loans at call.
call.translation[4].definitions[5].defin: a demand from a company to a shareholder to pay for shares that they have been given
call.translation[4].definitions[5].examp: The company is raising £155 million from the first call of 225p a share.
call.translation[4].definitions[6].defin: another name for CALL OPTION (=the right to buy shares etc at a particular price within a specific period of time)
call.translation[4].definitions[6].examp: Total options volume was 33,000, with puts at 19,000 outnumbering calls.
call.translation[4].definitions[7].defin: a decision that you have to make yourself
call.translation[4].definitions[7].examp: Buy or don’t buy - it’s your call.
